channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: This Washington Museum Sold Some of Its Art. But at What Cost?
item.description: The Phillips Collection sold three works and raised $13 million to buy contemporary art, but the decision has led to rancor within the 104-year-old institution.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Jonathan Newton/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C., is housed in the former family home of its founder, Duncan Phillips.

item.title: Security Lapse Allowed Protesters to Disrupt Performance, Met Opera Says
item.description: Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, said a security guard was absent from his post when two people climbed onstage at a performance of “Carmen.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Opera in 2024. A protest at a performance of “Carmen” on Friday night led to a scene of chaos and confusion.

item.title: Donald Glover Says He Had a Stroke That Prompted Him to Cancel His Tour in 2024
item.description: The rapper and actor, who performed in Los Angeles on Saturday, said doctors had also discovered a hole in his heart, prompting him to cancel his world tour.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Tyler, the Creators Camp Flog Gnaw
item.media:description: Donald Glover performing as Childish Gambino during Tyler, The Creator’s “Camp Flog Gnaw Carnival” at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles on Saturday.

item.title: A War Photographer for Whom the Battle Continues
item.description: Rockoff, who risked his life to photograph the brutality of the Khmer Rouge, has struggled ever since. Now he says his historic negatives have been taken from him.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley

item.title: How ‘The Beatles Anthology’ Got Gen X Hooked on the Fab Four
item.description: Young people coming of age in the Fab Four’s shadow rolled their eyes at the band’s boomer bona fides. The “Anthology,” now back after 30 years, changed all that.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ — Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo’s Never-Ending Press Tour
item.description: The pink-and-green-themed promotions were everywhere, with all the advantages and limitations that kind of marketing push entails.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: From left, Ariana Grande, and Cynthia Erivo greeted fans at Universal Studios Singapore last week.

item.title: Da’Vine Joy Randolph Loves Ocean Swims, Minus the Snorkeling
item.description: “I have a phobia of what lies beneath,” the Oscar winner said. “I don’t want to know what’s down there! Don’t touch me and I won’t touch you.”
item.dc:creator: Leigh-Ann Jackson

item.title: How 2 New Songs Made Their Way Into ‘Wicked: For Good’
item.description: Each witch gets a new number as part of an effort to flesh out the arc of the stage show’s second act.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: Louis C.K. Kicks Off Beacon Theater Shows With Quieter Approach
item.description: “Ridiculous,” the newest show of his prolific post-cancellation career, represents a break from the past along with continuity.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Louis C.K. at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan on Sunday.

item.title: Former Met Museum Chief Takes Over Philadelphia Art Museum
item.description: Two weeks after dismissing its director and chief executive, Sasha Suda, the museum has named her replacement: Daniel H. Weiss. It also responded to a lawsuit brought by Suda.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin

item.title: ‘Initiative’ Review: High School as an Epic Struggle
item.description: A new production at the Public Theater takes up five hours of stage time to tell the story of a group of friends from their first day to graduation.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: ‘Toy Story’ at 30: Animation Has Never Been the Same
item.description: The Pixar Era kicked off 30 years ago with the first installment of the popular franchise. It’s given us countless hits, but something has also been lost.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips

item.title: At 80, Anthony Braxton Is Easier Than Ever to Celebrate
item.description: With new releases and concerts, Anthony Braxton’s output as an artist and thinker is quickly available for longtime fans and initiates alike.
item.dc:creator: Seth Colter Walls
item.media:credit: Cody O'Loughlin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Several Anthony Braxton recordings have become available recently, and a concert series at Roulette in Brooklyn celebrated the composer across three Wednesdays in November.

item.title: Eurovision Tightens Voting Rules to Tamp Down on Government Influence
item.description: In this year’s contest, a campaign by Israel to encourage voting for its entrant drew criticism.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Israeli fans during a Eurovision Song Contest semifinal in Basel, Switzerland, in May.

item.title: ‘The Beatles Anthology,’ Plus 9 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The remastered documentary series will be released, and we watch some reader recommendations, including “The Gone” and “Dark.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’ Season 1, Episode 5 Recap: Search and Destroy
item.description: Gen. Shaw sends troops into the sewage tunnels under Derry. The children send themselves there, too. Bad idea in both cases.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Dick (Chris Chalk ) saw something in those tunnels. It seemed mostly to be in his head.

item.title: ‘Gruesome Playground Injuries’ Review: Does It Hurt?
item.description: Kara Young and Nicholas Braun star in the Off Broadway revival of Rajiv Joseph’s two-hander about best friends on parallel paths to self-destruction.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: At the Lucille Lortel Theater, the two-time Tony Award winner Kara Young, left, plays Kayleen opposite the “Succession” alum Nicholas Braun as Doug.

item.title: Why That Whitney Houston Drum Beat Is So Addictive, Yet Hard to Match
item.description: People online have been trying to nail the drumbeat before the final chorus of “I Will Always Love You.” It’s harder than it looks.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I think it’s fun,” he said of the interest in the song’s drumbeat. “It sort of made me rethink how long the pause is.”

item.title: Robert Irwin Spreads a Message of Love on ‘Dancing With the Stars’ and Beyond
item.description: His story began with loss, but the lessons of his “Crocodile Hunter” father have Irwin spreading a message of love on “Dancing With the Stars” and beyond.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer
item.media:credit: Jennelle Fong for The New York Times
item.media:description: With his success on “Dancing With the Stars,” and his upcoming cameo in “Zootopia 2,” Mr. Irwin sees a future for himself that will require more time spent in the United States.

item.title: Clean Comedy Is Back, This Time Without the Judgment
item.description: Nate Bargatze, Leanne Morgan and Dusty Slay are leading a family-friendly scene. Unlike earlier stand-ups, they don’t look down at their cursing peers.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: Dorothy Vogel, Librarian With a Vast Art Collection, Dies at 90
item.description: On modest civil servants’ salaries, she and her husband amassed a trove of some 4,000 works by art-world luminaries, storing them in their one-bedroom Manhattan apartment.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dorothy Vogel with her husband, Herbert, in a New York gallery in 1992. Their Manhattan rent-controlled apartment functioned as a fine-art storage locker as well as an exhibition space for thousands of works by contemporary artists.

item.title: Terry Martin Hekker, a Happy Housewife Scorned, Dies at 92
item.description: She wrote two popular memoirs: the first about the joys of married life, the second about her husband serving her divorce papers on their 40th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Terry Martin Hekker in an undated photo. “I’m one of the last of the dying breed of human females designated ‘Occupation: Housewife,’” she wrote in the late-1970s.

item.title: Stream These 5 Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix in December
item.description: Departures for U.S. subscribers next month include several classic comedies of the big and small screen — and one particularly prescient one.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.media:description: Terry Crews (second from left) and Luke Wilson (second from right) in “Idiocracy.”

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Tells a Story Through Color
item.description: Alice Brooks, the cinematographer of “Wicked: For Good,” explains the meaning and intention behind the color choices in the film.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr, Edward Vega, Gabriel Blanco and Laura Salaberry

item.title: How Shaboozey Won the Hearts of Country Music Fans
item.description: For years, the country music star struggled to stake a claim to the version of himself that now seems inevitable.
item.dc:creator: Lizzy Goodman
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shaboozey performing in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in October.

item.title: Miss Piggy, Fraggles and an Auction at the Twilight of a Hollywood Era
item.description: The Jim Henson Company sold its longtime studio and is auctioning Muppets memorabilia for the first time in its 70-year history.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Michelle Groskopf
item.media:description: Miss Piggy’s shoes from “The Great Muppet Caper” could go for $7,000 or “Hi-yah!”

item.title: How Gaten Matarazzo, the ‘Stranger Things’ Star, Spends His Day Off
item.description: Gaten Matarazzo, a breakout star of Netflix’s megahit horror series, attends Rangers hockey games with his dad and walks the Hudson River with his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Christian Rodriguez
item.media:description: Hudson River Park

item.title: Protesters Interrupt a Performance of ‘Carmen’ at the Met Opera
item.description: One of the protesters, who were arrested and removed from the hall, denounced the billionaire David H. Koch.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Marina Harss
item.category: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Protesters brought a performance of “Carmen” to a halt on Friday at the Met.

item.title: Burt Meyer, 99, Dies; Made Lite-Brite and Rock ’Em Sock ’Em Robots
item.description: Starting in the 1960s, he collaborated on the designs of classic toys like Mouse Trap, Toss Across and Mr. Machine.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Strong National Museum of Play (Rochester, NY)
item.media:description: Burt Meyer in an undated photo. “There was a little mischievousness in him,” another toymaker said. “He was joyful and playful, like a kid, and treated toy design as an art form.”

item.title: Review: Even With Olga Smirnova, Dutch National Ballet Falters
item.description: For its season at New York City Center, its first major engagement here in years, the company disappoints with mediocre repertory.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: Timothée Chalamet Draws Huge Crowd for ‘Marty Supreme’ Merch Pop-Up
item.description: Mr. Chalamet’s star power was in full force in Manhattan as fans clamored to get merch for “Marty Supreme,” a movie none of them will see until Christmas.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher and Graham Dickie
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times

item.title: Five Free Movies to Stream Now
item.description: For the Thanksgiving holiday, this month’s picks, including “Force Majeure” and “The Humans,” look at family togetherness in all its mundane glory.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
item.description: In this month’s picks, there is cloud busting in Peru, a shadowy astronaut drama, doomsday preppers in New Zealand and more.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: French Ideas, Made in the U.S.A.
item.description: The Chicago-born curator Naomi Beckwith has been given free rein at the Palais de Tokyo to examine how American artists responded to thinkers from France.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge

item.title: Watch a ‘Wonderful’ Moment From ‘Wicked: For Good’
item.description: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ariana Grande, Cynthia Erivo and Jeff Goldblum performing the song “Wonderful.”
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Zodiac Killer Project’: Hooked on True Crime
item.description: Charlie Shackleton explains how he would have made a film had he won the rights to a book on a murderer. The result is a fascinating look at a whole genre.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Jon M. Chu narrates a sequence from his film featuring Cynthia Erivo, Ariana Grande and Jeff Goldblum.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: ‘I’ll Go When You Go,’ Jimmy Kimmel Tells Trump
item.description: “Let’s ride off into the sunset together like Butch Cassidy and the Suntan Kid,” Kimmel said after the president demanded (again) that ABC take him off the air.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: ‘Two Strangers’ Review: Meeting Cute, Toting Baggage
item.description: The effervescent musical, a new London import, delivers lavishly on the promise of a rom-com: laughter, escape and fantasy.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes and Sara Krulwich
item.category: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York) (Play)
item.media:description: Sammy Tutty, left, plays the irrepressible Dougal opposite Christiani Pitts as the no-nonsense Robin in “Two Strangers Carry a Cake Across New York” at the Longacre Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: CIA Kryptos Auction: Anonymous Bidder Pays Nearly $1 Million for Secret to Decode Sculpture
item.description: The creator of the Kryptos panels, Jim Sanborn, sought to unburden himself of the puzzle, and then discovered before an auction he had archived its solution in the Smithsonian.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:description: Jim Sanborn, the artist who created the Kryptos sculpture, at the International Spy Museum in Washington earlier this month.

item.title: Frida Kahlo Portrait Sells for $55 Million, Setting Her Auction Record
item.description: The surrealistic self-portrait was made in 1940, a turbulent year in the Mexican artist’s life as her health and marriage deteriorated.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Tim F. Schneider
item.media:description: Bidding for Frida Kahlo, “El sueño (La cama),” or “The dream (The bed),” at Sotheby’s auction house in Manhattan. It sold for $55 million at auction Thursday night, breaking the artist’s record.

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure,’ Documentary About U.F.O.s, Gets a Congressional Audience
item.description: “The Age of Disclosure,” a documentary featuring government and military officials, was screened for a bipartisan group of members of the House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Ralph Blumenthal and Leslie Kean
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Justin T. Gellerson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The director Dan Farah at a showing of his film, “The Age of Disclosure,” in Washington.

item.title: David Bellos, 80, Dies; Wrestled French Wordplay Into English
item.description: He translated nearly 30 books, including novels by Georges Perec, a master of linguistic games, and Ismail Kadare.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: Who Owns This Sentence? A History of Copyrights and Wrongs (Book)

item.title: Richard Lamparski, 93, Dies; Wrote ‘Whatever Became Of …?’ Books
item.description: He turned an obsession with forgotten stars into a popular series, long before “Where Are They Now?” features became ubiquitous.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Superman Comic Sets Auction Record, Selling for $9.12 Million
item.description: A family’s forgotten copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was sold by Heritage Auctions.
item.dc:creator: George Gene Gustines
item.media:description: A high-grade copy of Superman No. 1, from 1939, was discovered by a family last year and sold for $9.12 million at auction.

item.title: After the Louvre Heist, the Museum’s President Defends Her Tenure
item.description: In one of her very few interviews since the museum heist, Laurence des Cars said the plan would increase much-needed security, but critics say it is too focused on new construction.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Elaine Sciolino
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laurence des Cars, the Louvre’s president, in the museum in 2023.

item.title: Senate Democrats Investigate Kennedy Center Deals With Trump Allies
item.description: Under Richard Grenell, the performing arts center has given steep discounts to CPAC and FIFA, signed contracts with administration associates and spent lavishly on friends.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: Richard Grenell at a White House dinner for the Kennedy Center board in May. Since he was tapped to lead the center, it has become something resembling a private club for the president’s friends and supporters.

item.title: ‘The Family Plan 2’ Review: A Relaxing Vacation? Maybe Not.
item.description: Mark Wahlberg and Michelle Monaghan return in a better executed, equally goofball sequel about a family’s tangles with organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: After 167 Years in New York, a Priceless Coin Collection Heads to Toledo
item.description: The doubloons, dollars and denarii of the American Numismatic Society will leave their overlooked home in Manhattan for a more welcoming headquarters on the campus of the Toledo Museum of Art.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry and Photographs By Todd Heisler
item.media:description: The American Numismatic Society has one of the world’s great coin collections, but few people currently see it.

item.title: Netflix Has a New House in the Suburbs: Come In and Chill
item.description: After a string of successful events and activities, the streamer has opened its first permanent home for branded fun, at a mall near Philadelphia.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Michelle Gustafson
item.category: Netflix House Philadelphia (King of Prussia, Pa)
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times

item.title: Arthur Jafa Crafts a Mixtape from MoMA’s Art
item.description: In “Artist’s Choice: Arthur Jafa,” the artist mines the museum’s vaults for an exhibition that gives new meaning to what he found there.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: Ruth Asawa Turned Wire Into Her Lifeline
item.description: Her undulating looped-wire sculptures and drawings of flowers hint at personal depths, in a major retrospective at MoMA.
item.dc:creator: Deborah Solomon
item.category: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
item.media:credit: Ramona Jingru Wang for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Art can only be taught by artists,” Asawa once said. “If a non-artist teaches a subject called art, it is nonart.”

item.title: Theater as a Safe Space? ‘Practice’ Demolishes That Idea.
item.description: Nazareth Hassan’s darkly witty satire follows an imperious director who pushes his eager actors to extremes.
item.dc:creator: Tim Teeman

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Review: Two Besties Till the End
item.description: Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande return to Oz for the second part of Jon M. Chu’s maximalist adaptation of the Broadway musical.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Train Dreams’ Review: Life, Understood in Reverse
item.description: Joel Edgerton stars in a gorgeous film based on Denis Johnson’s celebrated novella about a laborer in the Pacific Northwest.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter’ Review: When Fame Recedes
item.description: A documentary tracks the highs and lows of the 1990s fitness guru, now a food delivery driver in Las Vegas.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.category: Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter (Movie)

item.title: ‘Sisu: Road to Revenge’ Review: Slapstick Rambo
item.description: In this sequel to the 2023 exploitation film, blood-splattered inanity becomes a delirium of popcorn fun.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Rental Family’ Review: Brendan Fraser, Lost in Impersonation
item.description: Brendan Fraser is quietly endearing in this fish-out-of-water tale of an American actor in Tokyo who accepts some highly unusual assignments.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘Cutting Through Rocks’ Review: The Only Way Out
item.description: A documentary about Sara Shahverdi, the first woman elected to the council of her village in Iran, is propelled by her no-nonsense resourcefulness.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Linden

item.title: ‘The Age of Disclosure’ Review: Release the Extraterrestrial Files
item.description: A documentary argues that the U.S. government needs to divulge what it knows about the phenomena formerly called U.F.O.s.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Cactus Pears’ Review: Finding Intimacy Amid Grief
item.description: This understated Indian drama follows closeted gay man gingerly initiating a romance with an old friend.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: The Grand Ole Opry at 100
item.description: As the country music institution celebrates a century of its radio broadcast, listen to how the show defined the culture — and was reshaped by it — decade by decade.
item.dc:creator: Bill Friskics-Warren
